turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Was this him?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Um... he was older.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Besides that.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: To be honest, when I'm working, I don't look at faces much. He knew the guy's name.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Testa?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: The bearded guy, the creep. Oh, one other thing. Testa, if that's his name, he kept mentioning my feet. Said I had very pretty feet.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Have you had a chance to think about --

turns.speaker: DAITZ
turns.text: Zorro. Yes, ran it through my files, even asked around: came up completely blank. Thought there might be a Mexico connection, El Paso and all, but nothing. Fooled around with the letter "Z," turned it on it's side, got "N" -- there Ng, he's Vietnamese. The only thing that came to mind was zero, not Zorro. Remember Suspect Zero?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DAITZ
turns.text: Before your time. It was Richard Low's brainchild, or, lack-of-brain child. The Behavioral Sciences Unit at Quantico is essentially the product of three men: David Koessler, Dick Low and myself. Low was a field agent, Koessler administrative, I was teaching criminology. Low came up with the concept of a serial killer's signature. He invented profiling. Everything we know about profiling started with Richard Low...

turns.speaker: DAITZ
turns.text: ...well, there was some friction: I wanted to write up my work, educate the public, but Koessler wouldn't allow it. Low felt Koessler was more interested in career advancement than catching killers. Koessler had Low reassigned to the Pacific Northwest, Seattle. You know when they say, stick it where the sun don't shine? That's where they stuck Dick Low.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Pacific Northwest is a hotbed for serials.

turns.speaker: DAITZ
turns.text: You got that right. Low became obsessed with the Green River murders, the case had been inactive for ten years at that point. He argued the Green River Killer had actually become Suspect Zero, this master murderer who killed without pattern, killed literally hundreds of victims -- male, female, old, young, straight, gay -- and who was still killing, even though there were no bodies. It went against everything we knew. Low became increasingly paranoid. Every suspect was potentially Suspect Zero. Anybody tried to talk sense into him, he'd accuse them of being out to get him. Deputy Director Koessler was "out to get him." The decision was made to relieve him.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Does Koessler know about the Suspect Zero theory?

turns.speaker: DAITZ
turns.text: Of course. He knows everything about Dick Low.

turns.speaker: DUNCAN
turns.text: Welcome back, sir. How was the vacation?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Takes four days to chill, then its time to come back.  Is that...?

turns.speaker: DUNCAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Agent Duncan, there's an interstate issue up on 54, run out there.

turns.speaker: DUNCAN
turns.text: I'm babysitting the DEA guys this afternoon, Casio and I. You said that was top priority.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Agents Duncan, Mackelway.  Anything new?

turns.speaker: DUNCAN
turns.text: Just mopping up. Nine bodies in all.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Anybody talk to the press?

turns.speaker: DUNCAN
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: The diner?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You run the plates?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Fella's name is Harold Speck, travelin' man out of Roswell.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Excuse me, a salesman gets done in his car and you call the FBI?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Well, the victim was killed at the turn-around over there, then his car was pushed over here...  ...right across the state line. That makes it Federal. This is Officer Wallace, he's out of Alamogordo.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Where's the Nuevo American Diner?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Ten miles back on the Texas side.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I hope that wasn't a joke because I can assure you, from personal experience, the FBI does not have a sense of humor.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: That's right, Jan.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Nine bodies in Roswell, now this -- it's getting a little hairy, huh?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I'd appreciate it if you kept this to yourself.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: I know how the Feds like to sit on information. I got something in the car to show you.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Her name is Karen Sumpter, from near Dell City. Just disappeared a couple weeks back. Vanished.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You're thinking...?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Who knows.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: This isn't in our database?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: I just assumed she ran away. Happens a lot around here. Look around. This place is an invitation to run away.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Agent Mackelway.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Mack, this is Sheriff Dylan.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Oh Jesus, Sheriff, I am sorry. I meant to call you -- I got distracted -- the Sumpter girl was not one of Speck's victims. That's the good news.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: What's the bad news?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You tell me.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: No bad news. You know the Be On the LookOut you asked me to send on the diner car -- we got a hit on it. A little town on the border, Socorro. We got it staked out -- you interested?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I'm on my way.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Hey, Sheriff.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Down the road a piece is the Golden Sunset, the no-tell motel, Socorro's contribution to international relations. The car's just sitting there, no activity. I've had a couple Hispanic officers casing it all day. Want to take a look?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What does the Manager say?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: I sent a female in. The room in question was rented by an Anglo, cash; since then, nothing -- no activity, no phone response.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Let's take a look.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The room key's in the car. On the seat.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: And it's getting dark. I'm not going to run this into the night.  Eddie, we're walking in. Everything covered?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Show's over, boys. Nobody home.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Tape it off, we'll want to fine-tooth- comb it. My guess is that the UNSUB is having us on. He checks in, pays, picks up the key, but never walks inside. Tell me if I'm wrong.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Got a sister like this, what they call it, anal? That's her.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Dylan here.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Sheriff Dylan, this is FBI Agent Thomas Mackelway. Remember me?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Hi there.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I want to talk about the Karen Sumpter case.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: You heard?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Her body turned up. In a Minnesota cemetery. They brought her back.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You have the body?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: She's buried.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I want the autopsy report, where is it, Minnesota?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Winona.

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: The family has gone through a lot. Their daughter missing, the search, her body found, the funeral -- then this order to exhume the corpse.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I'm sorry. This won't take long.

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: The body was embalmed. I don't understand --

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Turn the body over. There was something in the autopsy report, yes, here.  These burn marks.

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: A grill pattern.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: We need to run this through VICAP, search for similar burns.

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: Ligature strangulation, just like his victims. A cord, nylon, you can tell by the indentation signature -- again, like his victims.  Look at that little thing and look at all the trouble it got him in. Should have cut it off.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: I'm not in the mood for Native American wisdom.

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: We had to bring staff in from the whole county to handle this.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: I appreciate it, doctor. You know how it is, press screaming for answers, Washington's all over me.  Ever handle a serial case?

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: Be my guest, Agent Kulok, scrub suits are in the back.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: This is Agent Mackelway.

turns.speaker: EAGLEFOOT
turns.text: Ripped off. By hand, my guess. Perimortal: victim was alive at the time, there's blood on his throat.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: That's the thing. Don't know if it connects, but Harold here had a thing about eyes. Two of the victims had their eyes gouged out, another punctured. Took polaroids after.

turns.speaker: FOREMAN
turns.text: There seems to be a discrepancy.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: Not a discrepancy, an error. My capacity is 5.5 tons, not 6.

turns.speaker: FOREMAN
turns.text: I have 6 tons.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: Mam, it's my truck. I know my own capacity.

turns.speaker: FOREMAN
turns.text: You can't imagine how many men have told me that.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: It's been customized for sleeping capacity.

turns.speaker: FOREMAN
turns.text: Oh yes, I see. You must get asked this a lot.

turns.speaker: ZERO
turns.text: Not as much as you'd think.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Hi. What's in the case?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You... surprised me.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Sorry. I've seen you in here. Always lugging that case around.  Whatja sell?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Ah... restaurant supplies. I didn't get your name.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You must travel a lot, huh?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Whole country or just hereabouts?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't mean to be rude, but...

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Just gettin' a jolt of java before headin' on home?  How does your wife feel about it?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: About your being away all the time. Must get lonely.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Look...

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You must get lonely. You ever think about, you know...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You know, you ever think about other women?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What are you...?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Fucking. I'm talking about fucking, Harold. You ever think of fucking other women?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Look, mister...

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Take a look, Harold. Tell me if you see anything you want. You do like to look, don't you?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: My God.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Not bad, huh?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You're a... you're sick.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: What's wrong with me?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Calm down, Harold.  Okay, here's what we're going to do, Harold: there's a pull off up ahead, we're going to stop there.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Oh God, mister, please leave me alone.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You're going to miss it. Pay attention.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What do you want from me?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: I've been looking for you.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Why me? What do you want from me!?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The man who was with him, he was a construction worker?

turns.speaker: JANITA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What did he look like?

turns.speaker: JANITA
turns.text: I didn't wait on him. Fifty or so, white, regular build, needed a shave -- that's all I remember.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: How did you know he was a construction worker?

turns.speaker: JANITA
turns.text: He had an orange hat on.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: He was sitting here?

turns.speaker: JANITA
turns.text: It's been wiped down a hundred times since then.

turns.speaker: JANITA
turns.text: There was a car in the lot when we closed. Gone today.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What kind?

turns.speaker: JANITA
turns.text: An old junker. Like a reservation car. Blue, side door with brown, you know, primer paint. New Mexico plates. A Ford or ah, yeah, a Ford.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Put a BOLO out on that.

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Speck's the killer all right. We got box loads of evidence. Did 'em all the same way: torture, strangulation. Prostitutes. I don't think we'll be able to write off any outstandings on him -- this is probably the full body count.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: What about his killer?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Nada. Vague description, that's all. Fine-tooth-combed Speck's car, the diner: no fingerprints, no trace evidence.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: What's with the eyelids?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You have the photo from the diner?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: At the field office.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Let's take a look at it.  Drop off my stuff at the hotel after you're done here.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: He said it was a clue?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Maybe something to do with Zorro.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Don't say that. Don't even think that. The next thing we'll be hearing about "Zorro Killer" in the media -- this hasn't gotten out, has it?

turns.speaker: SALINAS
turns.text: Just hospital talk. Nothing that connects to Speck.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: This could all be a coincidence, but, you know something, I don't believe in coincidences. That's why I came back.  Do you think the UNSUB -- we're not going to mention the word Zorro -- met Harold Speck online?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Chuck, hello.  This is Agent Kulok. She has a background in medical forensics.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Just an observer.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: We didn't know Speck was a serial, the police didn't know, his wife didn't know -- so how did the killer know?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Maybe cause he's smart.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Smarter than us.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Sorry to interrupt you, sir, but I thought you'd like to know.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: We have another one.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Another what?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Serial killer killed. In Ft. Myers. Cut up in his van. And this time we got a witness.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Deputy Director, get out, sir.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Mackelway, I could understand. He is over-emotional by nature, but you, Agent Kulok, you had a shining career in front of you.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Just step outside, sir. Now. Keep your hands where I can see them.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Look, sorry. Don't say a word.  I know this is improper. I've been trying to speak with Deputy Director Koessler. I left a message. I must speak with you before you go back to Washington.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: This better be important.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I think I talked to him.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Speck. Harold Speck.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: From the grave?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: MyDick.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I'll relay this to CIIAC.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: They don't know how to crack these secret chat rooms --

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I might point out, Agent Mackelway, the reason we haven't been able to crack those rooms is that you refused to share that information with us -- which is also why you were reassigned.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I had gotten their trust. We were sharing fantasies. I couldn't risk it.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is not based on personal preference. We share information.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Let some by-the-book J. Edgar Agents go into the chat room, spook these guys with stupid questions, blow my cover? -- no way.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You refused to comply with a direct order.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I was lucky to find, much less crack, the address code -- no way to be sure I could have done it again.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Its called insubordination.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Then why do I still have a badge?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: How do you feel, Agent

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Pretty embarrassed, to be honest. I had him.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Agent Kulok and I were in O'Hare when we heard.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: He got away. I had him. He got away.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Do you think he singled you out?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: No, just coincidence. He knew who I was, of course. He had my ID -- did he keep it?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: The cut on your arm -- mind if we remove the bandage?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Agent Mackelway, you're going to get your wish. You're going back to Washington. I want you back in Computer Crimes. Fire up those chat rooms.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: This time, sir, if I may be so bold, would it be possible to set up my equipment outside CIIAC, perhaps in military housing at Quantico? I didn't get along very well with the other members of the Division. We thought differently.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You didn't like anyone looking over your shoulder -- why was that? What were you doing?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: If my Reporting Agent could be someone outside Computer Crimes, perhaps Agent Kulok?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I'll take it into consideration.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What I do requires confidentiality.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I always meant to ask, what is it that makes you so special? Why is it you have this special rapport with multiple killers? Why you?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: They like my stories. They like the way I think. They're into fantasy. I turn them on.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You feeling okay, Agent Mackelway?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Had trouble sleeping last night, sir.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Okay, Harold Speck: who goes first?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Nothing concrete. Nothing I'd... well, nothing.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I don't believe this.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I'm hesitant to...

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Mack the Mouth at a loss for words.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: "Murman" was the alter identity of William Heirens, the original "Catch Me Before I Kill Again" killer. Short for "Murder Man." It was the case that got Richard Low and I started in this field.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I spoke with Lloyd Daitz.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: That gasbag. I can imagine what he said. I'm not ashamed to admit that most of what I know about criminal profiling started with Richard Low. I have also, over the years, I admit, taken credit for many of his accomplishments. He was the most brilliant law enforcement individual I ever met.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: "Was?"

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: We had every reason to believe he was on that plane. He was supposed to be on the plane. Everything was incinerated, it was two weeks before we reached the crash site. We, the Director and I, decided it was in everyone's best interest to declare Dick Low dead. That way he could exit a hero.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You suspected all along, suspected he was alive. That's why you came to El Paso.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Dunlevy said there was another case, Ron Rice. In fact, there were two earlier cases where serials were murdered. The second was George Sheldon. I didn't enter it into VICAP -- I'll get you the file.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: How long ago?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Both in the last year. I suspected only someone as brilliant as Dick Low could find these guys.  Look, whatever Daitz told you, nobody wanted to strip Richard of his badge. You have to get close to be good at what he did, the trick is not to get too close.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You knew the arm slash was not "Zorro."

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I suspected, but you were the one Low contacted. That's why I brought you back here.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What did you think of the Suspect Zero theory?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: It was neither a valid concept nor a valid fact. Suspect Zero came to represent every killer Dick Low had not caught. The idea took root in his head like a wild irrational vine. For someone like Low, there would always be a Suspect Zero. We couldn't let Richard go where that idea was taking him.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I got a look in Testa's computer. His screen name was "Imelda." Have to give him that, had a sense of humor.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Collected shoes too?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: We're waiting for trace evidence results on the Rice killing.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: We need to put out an NCIC inquiry.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: How do you send out an APB on a dead man?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Huh?, sir.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I want to catch Dick Low, more than you can imagine, but I cannot risk going public. What happens when the media finds out that a former FBI Special Agent, a founder of the Behavioral Sciences Unit, is not dead, but instead alive and killing people, not ordinary people, but, even worse, serial killers, making him some sort of white knight vigilante?  You keep at it. We'll find him, we'll find him in our own way.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Why did you go to Chicago?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I was visiting an old college friend.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You didn't tell anyone where you were?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: An oversight, sir, I apologize. I felt I needed to get away for a day. The pressure. Paid for my own ticket.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: I'm told you've asked for a Bureau cross-check of flight records to and from El Paso, Ft. Myers, Omaha, the Murman murder time frames.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I was looking for a pattern.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: That breaks my confidentiality stipulation.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I didn't use Low's name.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: There was talk of a file photo.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: In Ft. Myers before your instruction. Nowhere else, sir.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Watch out for Dick Low, he's a liar; he has his own world. There was a Junior Agent in Seattle, not unlike you, an Agent who fell under Dick's spell. He'd have done anything for Agent Low. Richard got this Agent to take a suspect to the crime scene, beat him up, force a confession -- all unauthorized, all illegal.  The Agent died that night, killed by the suspect. Richard Low got him killed. Worst of all, we had to hush it up, let the suspect go. The suspect was George Sheldon, the second man Richard killed.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: As far as the public knows, Richard Low is dead. And he will stay dead until we kill him.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: He's got you believing in Zero now too.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I need to get to Amarillo immediately.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Have you told Richard Low about Amarillo?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I can't. The chat room isn't open for another five days.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: We'll wait. Get online with Low, inform him of Zero's route -- we'll set a trap for him.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What about Zero, Darryl Hawkins?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Hawkins isn't the target, Richard Low's the target.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: There's a killer out there -- we know who he is. He could be stalking now.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Dick Low's a killer too.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You're as crazy as he is! He's right! You don't give a damn about saving lives at all! Fuck you!

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Miss me, Dave?

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Thank you, Rangers.  Put this man in the unmarked.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Don't you touch him.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You better hope the Director doesn't stop abruptly one day, David, you might break your nose.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You're a disgrace to law enforcement, to the Bureau -- and to me.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: How did a girl like me end up in a place like this?  The Deputy Director here, he believes in Tough Love. A cop's cop. Shape up or ship out, righto? Agent Kulok, when you get a chance you might want to check the victims of the recent serials. You'll find that some of them have been credited to other killers, some years ago. That's a Dave Koessler trick, find a pliant sociopath, preferably a dead one, attribute to him unsolved cases, clean up the backlog-looks great in the yearly report.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: You are so fucked up.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Suspect Zero, now there's an idea that doesn't look good on paper --

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: When I was at the rest stop, there was a young boy, maybe ten, and his mother. Darryl Hawkins, Zero, abducted the boy in the men's room. I tried to stop him. He cold-cocked me --

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Listen to this guy? Can you believe this? He'll never change. Born a liar, first word out of his mouth was a lie. Make up a story, always a story, any goddamn story, to save his ass.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Agent Kulok, that boy, as we speak, is in Hawkins' truck, probably still alive, in a dark refrigerated compartment, shivering in just a T- shirt: put yourself in his mind, freezing, terrified, wanting his mother. Put yourself in his mother's place, desperate, imagining the worst is happening as she pleads, back there at the rest stop, for someone, anyone, to listen to her. This is not hypothetical, this is real. It is happening now and you can do something about it.

turns.speaker: KOESSLER
turns.text: Shut the fuck up or I'll shut you up.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: You have to save this boy. Good exists in this world. I can prove it because you can, in your life, save this one person.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Thanks for the ride.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: They sort of got me on shit detail, no offense.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: None taken.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Maybe I shouldn't put it that way. I'm on my best behavior. I've got to watch what I say.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You used to be in the Behavioral Science Unit, right?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The Academy, then CIIAC.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I read your white paper. It's sort of like the Bible for what they're trying to do in Computer Crime.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: How long have you been downtown?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Five months. I love it.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You work with Koessler?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Not especially.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Why did he come out here? What's going on?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Beats me. He just asked me to come along, double-check the forensics.  What did you do to piss him off?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: This is a sexy case.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yeah, you know the vic's car, he was killed this side of the state line, the car then pushed across the border. This by an Unknown Subject, presumably the killer, who left no fucking evidence except the snapshot, which may or may not have been accidental.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Doesn't fit.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: This is no random killing, no one shot deal. The UNSUB has killed before; he's good at it. So what do we have?  We have someone who has killed before who kills someone who kills: a serial killer of a serial killer -- and who wants the FBI to know he exists.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: And who kills in the manner of his victim.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: That information's being withheld from the media.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: A very sexy case.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Some kids found you in a garbage dump.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Where's my watch? It's gone.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yes I do.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: It explains a lot.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Relax.  J. Edgar's greatest fear: a female with a badge.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The man knew how to dress.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Don't even go there. What's up?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Setting up. Technically, anyone in a chat room can be traced back to a screen address. But, by using punters, a correspondent literally punts his address around the world, through computers in countries that have no communication treaties. The correspondent becomes "ghosted," invisible.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: What about the chat rooms themselves?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: That's the beauty of the system. This is a fugitive chat room. It moves from place to place, chat rooms that are normally empty at certain hours: a gardening website, Chaucer buffs, a dating service. A pre- arranged code shows up in one of fifty porn rooms -- that's where I stumbled across it -- notifying "friends" to meet at a certain time, usually midnight to three Eastern Standard, at a certain website -- a deserted chat room, say, "How to Plant Perennials." Come Tuesday, twelve a.m., bingo, these like-minded deviates log on and start yakking it up: explicit sex crime gossip, who did what to whom, who wants to do what, when, why and how.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: That's part of the reason I dropped by. I need to learn this stuff.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The other reason?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You want to have dinner?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Working the net isn't that different from ordinary undercover work. You go into the community, walk their walk, talk their talk, gain their confidence.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: They're all criminals?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: No, no, no, most of them -- I used to think all of them -- are just fantasists, guys who get off telling degrading stories. When I came across this fugitive chat room, listened in, I started to think some might actually be real, that they'd gone live. The challenge was to figure out which was which. Then I had my disagreement with Koessler.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: "Gone live?"

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Chat jargon for moving from fantasy to real victims: "I went live last month."

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: This is some serious shit.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Taking a Stryker saw, cutting off the top of someone's cranium, pulling the brain out -- what's that, a day in Spring?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You got a point there.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: People end up in occupations for a reason. They may think not, but they do: occupations define us.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I was going to be a physician, I am a physician, but I kept drifting over to criminal psych. This seems to be the best of both. My parents still haven't forgiven me.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I was interested in two things: computers and crime. They sort of came together.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: And one other thing.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Sex.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Look at this fellow... or this one.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Grown man dressed like a clown. Does he really think he looks good?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: He thinks he looks young.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: What's this country coming to?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Take it to the next level. What are his fantasies, what turns him on, what kind of pornography does he like? If he could act out his fantasies, what would he do? Imagine yourself one of his victims, realizing your life is in his hands. What is he thinking?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: My guess: he's wondering whether to get more fries or go straight to the chocolate sundae.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Every cop has a story and every story has a girl. The girl in my story was fifteen years-old. She wore a pink angora sweater -- I can still see it -- one day, she disappeared. I told the police she wouldn't run away, I told them who to look for, but I was just a kid. I sat in the police station crying and crying. My parents took me home. The girl was my cousin and the man who abducted her was a teacher I'd had. He kept her alive a week before he killed her. The police could have saved her. Every time I see a photo of a victim I see her. That's what I want to do. I want to save her.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Me too.  Make any headway with "Zorro"?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: None. Can't find a thing. Nothing on file, nothing online. It's not a part of any known killer's signature.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I was thinking, maybe we should ask Professor Daitz. Nobody knows this stuff better.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: That's because he's a fucking wacko. Never met a self-promotion scheme he didn't like. What's he doing now?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: He's a consultant to a network TV program on Profilers. He gets a check every episode.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I ever get like that, just take me out in back and shoot me.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Don't be too harsh.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I saw him on a talk show once, talking about these killers like they were his friends. Not the victims, not the families of the victims, he doesn't talk about them. Blood money, that's what it is.  Did he hit on you?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: When you were his student? Did he come on to you?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Of course he did. He came on to every attractive student. Which bothers you most: that he exploits suffering or that he came on to me?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You must really think I'm a square, a computer nerd.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: No, Mack, I do not think you're a square and definitely not a nerd.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Why did Koessler assign you as my liaison?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Because you asked him to, stupid.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Oh yeah, I forgot.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: There are Agency regulations about this.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: "Intra-Agency fraternizing."

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: It's a no-no.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I've been thinking about this.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Does Koessler ask about me?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: He's called a couple times.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What did you tell him?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Just routine stuff.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Not about coming to see Daitz?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Not yet. Not about this, either.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Find the feet?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: No. Cut off while he was still alive, look at his wrists, damn near ripped his hands off trying to get free. Must have been screaming real loud when the killer chain-sawed his throat. Unfortunately, he'd soundproofed his van.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: We got an UNSUB walking around with four feet?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: We did find these, however.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: We're trying to match them with dump site bodies.  This we know is Carol Delview from Tampa, found her last Spring. This one --

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: The tattoo?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Sue Ann Hanson.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You mean --

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You found the body. She was one of Harold Speck's victims. In El Paso.  They're not just talking to each other, Mack, they're trading souvenirs.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Did they disconnect Testa's computer?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Not yet. This time they're waiting for you.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You should have seen the store manager at Parade of Shoes. She was inconsolable.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Murman and Imelda had been slipping into a private chat room. Low had poor old Testa drooling on the keyboard. Abduction fantasies, voyeurism, mutilation, teasing him with fetish elements. He is very good. I think it's safe to say Richard Low is Murman.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Mack, I'm sorry. I apologize. I should have called. I had no right to sneak in on you like that.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: No, Jaime, I apologize. I didn't... I had no right to speak to you like that.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I came over because I couldn't sleep and was lonely. I wanted to see you. I thought I'd surprise you.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You did.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Maybe we should back off a bit.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I can't. They trust me, they accept me. I've got their confidence.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: No, I mean maybe we should back off a bit, you and me.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: There's the Agency issue. I think Koessler may suspect something already. We're not on the best footing with him as it is.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: That's true.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Then there's the other issue.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You need time to think. About the case, about you and me.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I found a peephole into Deviant World. I'm gonna reach in and yank some of those creeps out.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: And nobody else can do that?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Not the way I can.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: That's my point. Remember, you're a cop pretending to be a deviant. It's not the other way around.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Don't confuse what we do with who we are.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I just need to go a little slow.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Jaime? Where are you?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Where are you? Everybody's looking for you.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I'm in Omaha. Get to the airport. There's been another one.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: My watch. He toyed with me. He sent me to Chicago.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You want to get him? Find something he wants. Get him to come to you.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Start killing people for real?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Suspect Zero.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: That's a crackpot theory. Everybody says so.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: But he believes in it. That's all that matters. He toyed with you, you toy with him. Convince him you've got a lead on Suspect Zero. Use Zero, you'll find Low.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: This feels like something out of a spy novel.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I guess I'm a little paranoid.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I met with Richard Low.  These are names of missing persons he has flagged. I'm double-checking every case, but I don't want to be too obvious about it. I marked the ones I'd like you to work on.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Slow down a second, you met with Low --

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: You were right. He found me.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: And you're working with him?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I need something tangible. To hook him. I told him I'd found the confidential file on the Suspect Zero theory.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Does one exist?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Probably. I told him Koessler had ordered the report, kept it secret.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Koessler doesn't know any of this?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I've decided to investigate Low's plane crash. While I'm at it, I thought I'd look at the cases Koessler worked with Low.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I'd be real careful if I were you.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: It's too late for that. I've gone ahead of the curve on this one. There's no turning back. When this is over, Koessler is going to be right or Low is going to be right or I'm going to be right, but not all of us.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: It's okay to be wrong, just don't be dead wrong.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: They say Richard Low is wrong, but because of him, women, innocent women, are alive who would be dead.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You're putting me in a difficult position.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I got an autopsy report from El Paso that doesn't seem right. A girl on Low's list. Karen Sumpter. We're getting a court order to exhume to body. I'd like you to come and look at it.  Don't worry, I've cleared it.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Jaime, do you think, when this is all over, when we're in different divisions, you think maybe you and me, we could try again?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Mack, I'm just trying to keep up with now.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: But why this pattern?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Could be a lot of things. Depends on the freezer.  I'm sorry, Mack, but I don't think this is the answer.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Tom, you okay?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Hardly anyone calls me Tom. Everybody calls me Mack. I always liked that.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Yeah, of course.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: It's quite advanced.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Burn marks. The original M.E. listed it as "burn residue." Same place, the outer thigh, as Karen Sumpter. The UNSUB is able to abduct, kill, transport and bury without detection.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: All the same killer?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Low calls him Suspect Zero.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Suspect Zero is a crackpot theory. You said so.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: That's what Koessler wants us to believe. To discredit Low.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: You're assigned, we're assigned, to apprehend Richard Low, not Suspect Zero. I have to tell you, Mack, I'm not comfortable where you're going.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: But it was your idea: "use Zero," you said, use Zero to get Low.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I haven't changed anything.  Damn.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I've got to take a piss.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Jaime --

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: It's a truck. A refrigerated truck.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Zero abducts victims all over the country, kills them, keeps them refrigerated for days, weeks, even months, then buries them hundreds, thousands of miles away. Karen Sumpter was buried, washed up in a flood. Evans was buried. When we get Zero, we'll find boneyards all across the country.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: How are we going to find him?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: Get the routes of all refrigerated trucks over the last ten years. We've got three disappearance cities and dates, three parallel discovery cities. Get into the mainframe, let it crunch this information.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: I'm going to Amarillo.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Agent...

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Kulok.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Agent Kulok, could you wipe my face?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Unlock these cuffs.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Sit back.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Mack must think Zero has a police band.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Of course he does. Now get the key, get these things off me.  Unhook me.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Uncuff me. What's wrong with you? Don't you want to save the boy?

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I want to protect the boy. I also want to protect Suspect Zero -- from you.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Okay, I'll unhook you. No weapon.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: No weapon.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: Turn around. Stretch your arms over the seat.

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: Bitch! Cunt! Please, please, please don't do this, Agent Kulok. You need me.

turns.speaker: KULOK
turns.text: I'll be back.

turns.speaker: MACKELWAY
turns.text: How did you know Speck was a killer?

turns.speaker: LOW
turns.text: The little piggie speaks.
